ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Close reading; deeper engagement with content (both through writing and discussion); ability to analyze individual texts while also considering the larger context of the syllabus.

I developed my writing and analysis. I was unfamiliar with many of the texts we read this semester and the movements they fell under, so I had to analyze things such as context a lot more. I think I know have a better understanding of the modern novel and the varying styles incorporated by these famed authors.
Close reading; group discussion; analysis of modernism and postmodernism.

I have improved my ability to look at literary texts holistically and situate them in a greater literary context (e.g romanticism, realism, modernism); I have learnt to identify and extract key stylistic pointers from a close-reading of the text that may help me relate it and compare / contrast it to other texts on the syllabus. Extensive, engaging thematic discussions on the books on the syllabus has improved my confidence and ability to express my views clearly orally; the stylistic connections that I draw between different genres of art (literature, visual art, music) have become more distinct.
I learned about Western literature from Petrarch to the 20th century. I wrote three essays and received feedback that has been critical to making me a clearer writer.
Literary discussion, interdisciplinary examination of literature, politics, and philosophy, huge emphasis on literary movements
Literature from Don Quixote to Omeros. This course shaped my writing and oral skills as well as my abilities as an independent thinker
I gained a better understanding of close reading and engaged with the texts of DS through a critical/literary theory lens.

In this literature course, I fostered really great close reading skills and analytical tools to apply to texts I read. I can delve deeper in my writing, and construct general points referring to broader themes. I drew important connections across the Western canon, and I can see a much clearer bridge between antiquity and modernity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I don't really think there are any weaknesses. Professor Bassi had a tun of fun activities to improve engagement, and the work we were assigned before class always enriched our discussions. I think she did a phenomenal job!
I thought the selection of texts was wonderful.

Strengths:
I think that the one-lecture two-discussion section division of the DS courses more generally works extremely well, where the lecture provides an overview and interesting avenue into the text while the discussion sections enables the students to interact with it more directly as they discuss and consider it together with their peers.

To me, the most thought-provoking and valuable lectures were those that started with a short biographical situating of the text, and then provided a distinct, in depth reading of it thatbecause it did not attempt to do everythingwas able to go into great detail regarding a certain aspect of the work. Examples of such lectures include: the lecture on Frankenstein, on A Raisin in the Sun, on Hadji Murat as well as both lectures on Paradise Lost.

Weaknesses:
If I compare the DS literature syllabus in the Spring to e.g the H&P Spring Syllabus or the Fall literature syllabus, it felt slightly less coherent. Personally, I think that less time could have been spent on Paradise Lost (perhaps not reading the work in its entirety?) and that we should have read more of Wordsworth's Prelude rather than combining it with a selection of his poetry. It would have been valuable (and related back to Goethe!) to read some modernist literature from the continent (e.g Kafka), and while I understand that reading Tolstoy's Hadji Murat is a more realistic project than tackling one of his most famous works, I believe I would almost have preferred reading selections from Anna Karenina, because it connects so well with Flaubert.

While it was a very engaging play, I think that the reason for picking 'A Raisin in the Sun' above any other text from the mid-20th century was not very clear. Similarly, 'Omeros' was incredible, but unfortunately I believe that a lot of students ended up not finishing it because it was a difficult text to end the semester with, especially since we had already started studying for Finals.

Strengths: I think DS Literature in general has a carefully crafted syllabus and is well-taught. Prof. Bassi's section in particular was excellent; we got to engage more deeply with the texts by exploring Yale's archival and museum resources, participate in creatively structured discussion sections, and explore not just the texts themselves, but also classical reception and literary criticism. 

Weaknesses: none
Strengths: interesting works, fun essay topics; Weaknesses: lots of reading
It covers a lot of material but not in great depth

Professor Bassis section was fantastic, but it often (every text with the exception of the troubadours and Paradise Lost) felt like we didnt have enough time to discuss it in the depth the texts merit. I think trimming a few texts from the syllabus would be valuable, and also would make room for a wider range of texts (including more non-English texts). I think the troubadours and Petrarch could safely be relocated to the first semester, and the second semester could start with Don Quixote.

There were so many amazing activities Serena planned, including fishbowl discussions and gallery visits. There were countless avenues to engage with textual content beyond just what we read. Maybe the essential themes of the texts could be specified, instead of leaving them up to question, deeply rooted in the works directly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely. As with all DS courses, the pace and workload made the class difficult to keep up with at some points, but class discussions and the opportunity to learn from Professor Bassi make the course worth the challenge.
I would recommend this course and Directed Studies to other students. I think if they enjoy the humanities, writing, and reading, they will surely have fun.
Yes, most definitely.

Yes! My entire section became friends through DS, which I believe was a direct result of Prof. Bassi's emphasis on groupwork, collaboration, and allowing everyone to get to know each other as people whose ideas and creativity should be respected.
yes yes yes! Any course by Bassi is bound to be intellectually enriching, fun, and worthwhile.
Yes! It develops a set of skills that any well-rounded person needs
Yes! It was always the highlight of my week.
